title: The Goldilocks Rule
summary: The Goldilocks Rule states that humans experience peak motivation when working on tasks that are right on the edge of their current abilities—not too hard, not too easy. To maintain motivation, you must work on challenges of just manageable difficulty. This is where you enter a state of flow.
keyIdeas: Peak motivation occurs when tasks are just manageable—not too hard, not too easy.
The Goldilocks Rule: work on challenges that are right on the edge of your abilities.
Boredom, not failure, is the enemy of long-term success.
As you improve, you must continue to raise the difficulty to stay engaged.
The sweet spot for motivation is 4% beyond your current ability.
Flow state occurs when challenge matches skill level.
Keep habits challenging enough to be interesting but easy enough to be achievable.
examples: Increase your running distance by 5% each week to stay challenged.
Add one new word to your vocabulary study each day.
Gradually increase the difficulty of your workouts as you get stronger.
Level up your habits as you master the current level.
exercises: Identify one habit where you can increase difficulty by 4%.
Create a progression plan for a habit to keep it in the Goldilocks zone.
Find the sweet spot where a habit is challenging but not overwhelming.
reflections: Which habits have become too easy and need more challenge?
How can you keep your habits in the Goldilocks zone of optimal difficulty?
